advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT, APRIL 1987</strong></font><br><blockquote>From Personal Computer World magazine.<br> Advert said:<br><font color="#666666"> It's an extraordinarily powerful machine which offers word-processing, spreadsheet, and a set of time and data-management tools in a single, highly porlable package.<br> At £199.95. the Z88 is supplied with 32K resident RAM. Extra 32K costs under £20, extra 128K under £50!<br> And heavy users Will be able to expand the RAM to an astonishing 3 Mbytes, using plug-in RAM cartridges.<br> For printing text or data, the Z88 connects direcly to most popular RS232 compatible printers, while for permanent storage the Z88 employs removable solid state EPROM cartridges - no tape to break, no delicate disc to damage.<br> Though the Z88 is a powerful, full facility, self-contained computer, it also acts as an extension of an office micro, connecting directly to allow exchange of text or data.<br> For every personal computer user, the Z88 offers a comprehensive specification in a package of unparalleled portability.</font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH BROCHURE #3</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Jacques Sorro</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERTISEMENT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>She seems quite happy with her new MB-H1 !<br> Do you think japanese girls used to bring their H1 to school ?!</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, FEB 1982</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>>  GERMAN LEAFLET #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Preliminary/New product leaflet. For exhibitions only<br><br><br> "The new Personal Computer from SHARP - particularly developed for personal use."<br><br> Note the optional Quick Disc drive.<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.sharpmz.org</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT NOV. 1987</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><font color="#666666"> Compaq has long been recognized as the world leader in both 80386 technology and portable computing. Si it's not surprising that we would combine the two.<br> But no one expected the new Compaq Portable 386 to run at 20 MHz. And no one even dreamed that it would offer 100 MB of storage, disk caching, and much, much more...</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is an official advert from Hewlett-Packard. It says "The easy touch".</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US BROCHURE (VERSO)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Chris Collman for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.guiguy.com/Schiff/" target="_blank">www.guiguy.com/Schiff/</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMO PIC #1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> BRAZILIAN ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.museo8bits.com" target="_blank">www.museo8bits.com</a> for this advert</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> QL CATALOGUE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote>''The Sinclair spirit is in him''</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (FEBRUARY 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ARTICLE</strong></font><br><blockquote>...released in "l'Ordinateur Individuel" magazine n°12<p class="petitgris">Thanks to Fabien Neck and its <a href="http://www.system-cfg.com/" target="_blank">website</a> for this scan</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC.1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Valric-Laurène was the french importer of the Spectravideo SV-318.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC.1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is an advert for Victornet, the net for Victor computers, based on Omninet.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US BROCHURE (RECTO)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Chris Collman for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> MICROSOFT ADVERT (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">No one knows better than Microsoft how to increase your TRS-80 BASIC's power. Microsoft created the TRS-80 Level ll and Disk BASIC plus the industry standard Microsoft BASIC...<br><br> ...Microsoft Level lll BASIC is an enhancement to the Level ll. It contains all Disk BASIC features not already in Level ll and it adds six new Level lll exclusives...<br> ...Advanced graphics is Level lll's most exciting addition to the TRS-80 - and it's exclusive. Draw a line, outline or solid box by specifying just two points, then save it and put it back with BASIC statement. You'll find yourself writing more programs with charts, graphs and even animation...</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD #1 (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The HHC advertising campain was not really attractive: black & white, lots of small characters texts, small pictures...</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST AD.</strong></font><br><blockquote>January 1983<br><br> Telcon needed customers payments before manufacturing the systems:<br><br><font color="#666666"> Upon receipt of your check, we will forward an end-user agreement. Allow 6 to 8 weeks for delivery of the units. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEW ZEALAND ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>From left to right arrow, advert says:<br><font color="#666666"> Redesigned front panel. Totally synchronous logic design. Same switch and LED arrangement as original Altair 8800. New back.lit Duralith (laminated plastic and mylar, bonded to aluminum) dress panel with multi.color graphics. New longer, flat toggle switches. Five new functions stored on front panel PROM inc1uding: DISPLAY ACCUMULATOR (displays contents of accumulator), LOAD ACCUMULATOR (loads contents of the 8 data switches (A7.AO) into accumulator), OUTPUT ACCUMULATOR (Outputs contents of accumulator to I/O device addressed by the upper 8 address switches), INPUT ACCUMULATOR (inputs to the accumulator from the I/O device), and SLOW (causes program execution at a rate of about 5 cycles per second for program debugging). <br><br> Two, 34 conductor ribbon cable assemblies. Connects front panel board to front panel interface board. Eliminates need for complicated front panel/bus wiring. <br><br> New front panel interface board buffers all lines to and from 8800b bus. <br><br> Rugged, commercial grade Optima cabinet. <br><br> Full 18 slot motherboard. <br><br> New CPU board with 8080A microprocessor and Intel 8224 clock generator and 8216 bus drivers. Clock pulse widths and phasing as well as frequency are crystal controlled. Compatible with all current Altair 8800 software and hardware!. <br><br> New, heavy duty power supply: +8 volts at 18 amps, + 18 volts at 2 amps, -18 volts at 2 amps. 110 volt or 220 volt operation (50/60 Hz). Primary tapped for either high or low line operation.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Murray Moffatt</b> from New Zealand</p></blockquote>

computer.description:
The Franklin ACE 500 was a 100% Apple IIe and Apple IIc compatible computer with a built-in 5.25" disk drive and 256 KB of RAM.
It looked pretty much like a black //c, featured all of the standard Apple ports and a better keyboard with a numeric keypad. It was also very similar to the Laser 128 in design and features.
The ACE 500 was the last Apple II compatible Franklin manufactured. Its capabilities and abilities were identical to the Ace 2000 series. The Company was sued in 1982 by Apple for copyright and patent infringement and ceased making computers in August 1983.
computer.graphics: All of the Apple IIc modes: 40 x 48 (16 col) / 80 x 48 (16 col) / 280 x 192 (6 col) / 140 x 192 (16 col) / 560 x 192 (mono)
computer.keyboard: Full stroke 90 keys with function keys and numeric keypad
computer.name: ACE 500
computer.ports: Parallel, Serial, NTSC RGB and composite video, joystick, mouse
computer.ram: 256 KB expandable to 512 KB on board

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> BACK SIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote><b>(1)</b> Serial port DIN plug<br> <b>(2)</b> Configuration switches<br> <b>(3)</b> Parallel DB25 connector<br> <b>(4)</b> External drive unit DB15 connector<br> <b>(5)</b> Mouse and Joystick DB9 connector<br> <b>(6)</b> RGB video out DB9 connector<br> <b>(7)</b> Monochrome composite video out RCA jack<br> <b>(8)</b> DC power plug. An external AC adaptor provides power.<br></blockquote>
